bibl.title: Letter from W.W. Norman to Howard A. Kelly, November 4, 1922

div1.p: Norman writes regarding changes proposed for “Walter Reed and Yellow Fever.“

div1.head: Letter from W.W. Norman to Howard A. Kelly, November 4, 1922
div1.opener:
The NORMAN, REMINGTON Co.
CHARLES ST. AT MULBERRY
BALTIMORE
BOOKS
STATIONERY
ENGRAVING
PRINTING
November 4, 1922
Dr. Howard A. Kelly,
1406 Eutaw Place,
City
Dear Dr. Kelly;-
div1.p:
I have just returned to town from
eight or nine days in the country where I went to take a
rest, and I find your letter of October 25th awaiting me.

When I agreed to make the minor changes
in the plates as well as the additional chapter on Gorgas,
I assumed that such changes would mean no more than the
cutting out of an occasional word and the substitution of
a revision. Certainly the idea of such material alterations
as the revised manuscript shows was not in my mind. I do
feel that we should not be called upon to assume this expense,
and I suggest that a fair compromise would be for us to pay
the cost of adding the Gorgas chapter, and an amount sufficient
to cover the cost of making the minor changes if it had been
possible to make them by excisions of the plates affected; the
balance of the cost would be undertaken by you.

The question of distribution and exploiting
would naturally have to receive a lot of attention at our hands,
since we should be under considerable expenditure in printing
the book. I have not given this question any thought, but
as soon as the work is put in hand, I shall call our Advertising
Agent into consultation and decide upon the best means of selling
the book in confidence with him.

In regard to the cyclopedia our Advertis-
ing man is preparing the scheme of a campaign which will begin
in January. The work is not particularly susceptible of Christmas
stimulus, and Mr. Corner suggests that we can do better work
after the Christmas rush is over.

I have asked the Bookkeeper to prepare a
statement of the sales since the last statement, and shall send
it to you as soon as it is ready.
div1.closer:
Yours sincerely, W.W. Norman
THE NORMAN, REMINGTON CO. N/Mc
